How Sexist Marketing Led to a Wider Gender Gap in the Technology Industry
Between the 1960s and 1990, the share of women making up the computer technology industry steadily rose from 27% to 35%. The task of programming and performing calculations was usually assigned to women – litteraly called computers – because it was not high-status work at the time. Men focused on hardware instead. However, around 1984 there was a significant drop in interest and graduation rates of women in Computer Science. How can we explain this demographic shift?

During my research, I have found that the answer points back to the popularization of the personal computer and how it was mainly marketed towards boys. In contrast, parents were encouraged to purchase dolls and easy bake ovens for their daughters. In this curator project, I will present primary sources and data from the National Center for Education Statistics with the aim of establishing a causal relationship between marketing and the previously mentioned demographic shift.
Margaret Hamilton 1969
The image to the left is a photograph from 1969. Margaret Hamilton and her team were in charge of writing all of the assembly code for the Apollo 11 mission. The photograph shows her standing with all of the software created for the iconic space mission.
Univac Computer in the 1950s.
Pioneers of the software world, women are the reason we have computing as we know it. Their male collegues tended to focus more on the hardware than the software as it was considered of higher importance.
Easy Bake Oven Advertisement 1981
In the Kenner ad, you can see a little girl enjoying her easy bake oven. Her mother and sister also join her and they look content with their culinary creation. This female multigenerational cast solidifies the message that this product in intended for women only.
Apple II Advertisement 1985
The ad, shows Brian Scott an American little boy with big dreams of becoming an astronaut. The Apple II is the tool he needs to help him achieve those ambitions. In the ad, you can even see him mess with his female classmate as she uses the product.
This plot was created with data from The National Center for Education Statistics
As you can see the gender gap widens after 1995. It is important to keep in mind that the Computer Science Bachelor may not have been popular in the early days of computing, so this plot starts 1970. However, advertisements in the 70s and 80s may have deterred more women from even considering the major in later decades. link

What does this tell us about American Capitalism? It seems that, after World War II, women were pushed back to the domestic box. Why is that important for our capitalistic society? Is it a question of homemaking and reproduction for increased productivity and labor?
